course.post_content: For this module of the Virtual Expedition Training for DofE, Chief Scout’s Platinum, Chief Scout’s Diamond and King’s Scout Award we’re looking at the kit you’ll need and how to set out your campsite.

_tutor_course_benefits:
Where to get your kit
What to wear
Managing your camp well
How to choose where to camp

categories.name: Bronze
categories.description: Materials targeted at bronze award participants.

categories.name: Silver
categories.description: Materials targeted at silver award participants.

children.post_content:
Where to get your kit

See the attached kit guide (in the "Exercise Files" tab) for a comprehensive guide to your expedition kit.

Before spending money, consider these three levels of sourcing kit to keep your budget in check.

  • Level 1: Borrowing. Ask friends or family for items like hats, sun cream, water bottles, or even rucksacks and tents.

    • Pro Tip: You may be able to borrow from your unit or district, don't forget to check with them.

  • Level 2: Use What You Have. Most participants already own a torch, a plastic bowl, and sports tops.

    • Crucial Exception: Avoid borrowing or buying second-hand walking boots; they have already moulded to someone else's feet and are likely to cause you pain.

  • Level 3: The DofE Card. If you must buy new, use your DofE Card (Digital or Physical) for at least 10–15% off at GO Outdoors, Blacks, Millets, Ultimate Outdoors, and Tiso. You can get the card here - https://www.dofe.org/shop/card/
children.post_title: Where to get your kit (the smart way)

children.post_content:
Choosing good boots

Your feet are your "engine." If they fail, the expedition stops.

  • Ankle Support is Mandatory: For DofE expeditions, you must wear walking boots, not walking shoes or trainers. You need support to prevent your ankles from twisting under the weight of a heavy pack.

  • The Deep Tread: Look for "M-D Traction" or deep lugs on the sole. This prevents slipping on wet grass or mud.

  • The Fit Test: Wear your expedition socks when trying on boots. Slide your foot forward until your toes touch the front; you should still be able to fit one finger down behind your heel.

  • Break Them In: Buy your boots months in advance. Wear them around the house, then on short walks, to avoid "expedition-ending" blisters.

  • Act Fast: On your expedition, deal with any hot-spots right away, before they form into blisters that could end your expedition

DO NOT wear trainers, walking shoes or trail running shoes. They lack the ankle support necessary to walk safely with an expedition pack, and your expedition supervisor may not permit you to proceed.

Good socks are vital

  • The "No Cotton" Rule: Like clothing, socks should never be 100% cotton. Cotton holds moisture against your skin, softening it and making blisters inevitable. Use wool-blend or synthetic "technical" socks.

  • Padding and Cushioning: Look for socks with reinforced "shock zones" at the heel and toe. This provides extra comfort and protection against rubbing.

  • The Liner Strategy: Some people find it good to wear a thin "liner sock" under your main walking sock (some socks are also constructed this way). The two layers rub against each other, reducing friction on your skin. Opinions vary, but it may be worth a try.

  • Try Them Together: Always wear your expedition socks when trying on boots to ensure the fit is correct.

The 3-layer clothing system

Adapting to the weather is about layers, not one big heavy coat.

  1. Base Layer: Moisture-wicking fabric (synthetic or merino wool). This pulls sweat away from your skin so you don't get cold when you stop.

  2. Mid Layer: A fleece. This traps warm air. Zips are great for regulating temperature while walking.

  3. Outer Layer: A waterproof and breathable jacket/trousers. "Waterproof" is better than "water-resistant."

Depending on conditions, you can wear just a base layer and your waterproof; or leave your waterproof in your bag.

The Golden Rule: NO DENIM OR COTTON. Leave your unit hoodie at home. Jeans and cotton hoodies are dangerous on expeditions. They absorb water, become extremely heavy, take days to dry, and strip your body of heat, which can lead to hypothermia.

Trousers

The three layer system can apply to your trousers too, with the difference that in summer you may not need a base layer. Choose trousers that are made of synthetic fibres so they dry quickly.

You must also have waterproof trousers. Make sure they have a zip on the side so you can put them on without taking your boots off.

Socks

Comfortable, non-cotton socks are vital for a comfortable expedition. Choose warm, well padded socks that help your boots fit well.

How to pack your rucksack

  • The 25% Rule: Your fully packed rucksack must not exceed 25% of your body weight, ideally less. (Example: If you weigh 60kg, your bag should be 15kg max).

  • The "Weight Distribution" Method:

    • Bottom: Lightweight, bulky items (Sleeping bag).

    • Middle (Against your back): Heaviest items (Stove, fuel, heavy food).

    • Top/Outer Pockets: Essentials you need quickly (Waterproofs, map, snacks, first aid).

  • Waterproofing: Don't rely on the rain cover, assume you are going to be unpacking your kit in the wet. Compartmentalise your kit so you can take it out without individual items getting wet. Use dry bags if you have them, but plastic bags will do fine.

question.question_title: Denim jeans are an acceptable choice for a Bronze expedition if the weather forecast is sunny and dry.
Which of the following items should you AVOID buying second-hand or borrowing?

contents.post_title: How to Run a Good Camp

children.post_content:
Selecting Your Perfect Campsite

Finding the right spot to pitch your tent is the difference between a great night's sleep and a cold, damp disaster. Look for the "Three Fs":

  • Flat & Firm: Your campsite must be as level as possible. Sleeping on a slope means you’ll slide to the bottom of your tent all night. Ensure the ground is firm enough to hold tent pegs but not so rocky that they bend.

  • Flow & Drainage: Avoid the "bottom of the bowl." If it rains, water will pool in hollows. Choose slightly elevated ground that allows water to drain away from your tent.

  • Fire Safety: Stoves must be used on a firm, level surface at ground level. Keep your cooking area away from tent fabric and ensure the area is clear of long, dry grass.

Waste Management: Leave No Trace

A great motto for the countryside is: "Take nothing but pictures, leave nothing but footprints."

  • Pre-Expedition Prep: The best way to deal with trash is to not bring it. Remove unnecessary cardboard and plastic packaging from your food before you pack your rucksack.

  • The "Nappy Sack" Method: Keep a dedicated bag (like a bin bag or nappy sacks) for your group's trash. Never leave trash at a campsite or tie it to the outside of your rucksack where it can fall off.

  • The Final Sweep: Before your team departs a campsite, perform a sweep. Walk across the entire area to check for "micro-litter" (like tiny corners of granola bar wrappers) and forgotten tent pegs.

Hygiene & "The Trowel"

At most of the places you will camp on your expedition, there will be no toilet facilities. Read the attached leaflet about how to go to the toilet when you're out hiking.

  • Distance: Always go at least 30 meters away from water sources (rivers/lakes) and your campsite.

  • The Cat Hole: Use a lightweight trowel to dig a hole at least 15cm deep.

  • Pack it Out: Used toilet paper and hygiene products should be placed in a sealed bag and carried out with your trash.

question.question_title: Which of the following is the best campsite option?
question.question_description: Look at the maps below and pick the one that you think represents the best campsite. Consider the type of ground, how you will get there, proximity to other land users and so on. Remember that you can\'t only tell from the map, you have to use your judgement on the ground.
question.answer_explanation:
The option by Affric Lodge is right next to buildings and so is not an appropriate camping site.

The option by Athnamulloch in is boggy grounde.

The option by the ruin south of the river is potentially good, but the path is on the other side of the river and there is no bridge.

The option north of the river by the fords is the best potential campsite of these four.

Of course, when you check it out in real life, vegetation or other factors may mean it is not a good option either, but it\'s the one I\'d check first.

question.question_title: What is the most important factor when choosing a spot to use your cooking stove?

answers.answer_title: Inside the tent porch to stay dry
On top of a large flat rock under a tree
In the middle of the group\'s circle of rucksacks
On a firm, level surface at least away from your tents

question.question_title: Before leaving a campsite, your team should perform a ___________ to ensure no micro-litter or tent pegs are left behind.
It is acceptable to leave biodegradable waste, like orange peels or banana skins, in the bushes because they will eventually rot.
When \"wild\" toileting, you must go _________ nearby water sources

answers.answer_title: A couple of metres away from
